docs.lead_paragraph: Some of the ornaments on the granite fountain are missing and it no longer spews water. Stretches of the wrought iron fence are broken and twisted. And the lawns are blotchy from neglect. Bit by bit, over the years, Madison Square Park, nestled in a corporate canyon just north of the Flatiron Building at 23rd Street and Broadway, has been losing its charm, even as its neighborhood prospers.

headline.main: Restoring the Charm to Madison Square Park

docs.abstract: City Parks Foundation says giant businesses that surround Madison Square Park will share cost with New York City of $5 million park restoration, set to begin in Jan; foundation and park neighbors seek to raise added $6 million for trust to pay for park director, gardener and workers to maintain grounds; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bruce DeHaven considers himself an exception to the rule. Not only has DeHaven had a steady job as an assistant coach in the National Football League for the past 12 years, he has also spent his coaching career with one team, the Buffalo Bills.
docs.abstract: NFL Coaches Association is pressing to lower pension eligibility requirements for assistant coaches and win them standard severance package; notes assistants are often forced to change jobs and few qualify for pensions; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Bruce DeHaven considers himself an exception to the rule.    Not only has DeHaven had a steady job as an assistant coach in the National Football League for the past 12 years, he has also spent his coaching career with one team, the Buffalo Bills.

docs.lead_paragraph: Former Senator Bill Bradley said today that the three most important differences between him and Vice President Al Gore were national health insurance, handgun control and a commitment to campaign-finance reform. Addressing a town meeting held to provide footage for his television commercials, Mr. Bradley said his rival for the Democratic presidential nomination was basically cautious. ''It has, for example, been the doctrine of the Democratic Party since the beginning almost of the modern Democratic Party that Democrats stand for universal access to affordable, quality health care,'' Mr. Bradley said. ''I provide it. He does not provide it.''

headline.main: Bradley Says 3 Issues Set Him Apart From Gore

docs.abstract: Bill Bradley lists three differences between him and Vice Pres Al Gore: says Gore dismisses his plan for universal access to health insurance as too costly; says Gore favors requiring new buyers of handguns to obtain licenses, while he, Bradley, wants licensing and registration of all handguns; says he and Gore favor ban on so-called soft money campaign contributions, but that he, Bradley, is more committed to issue (M)
docs.snippet: Former Senator Bill Bradley said today that the three most important differences between him and Vice President Al Gore were national health insurance, handgun control and a commitment to campaign-finance reform.     Addressing a town meeting held to...

docs.lead_paragraph: So, did it work? Whatever else can be said about Wisconsin's crusade to end welfare -- whether one judges it kind or cruel, whether one thinks it left the safety net stronger or in shreds -- the effort achieved two things.

headline.main: Bold Effort Leaves Much Unchanged for the Poor

docs.abstract: Last article of series, Life After Welfare, finds that Wisconsin's crusade to end welfare has left far fewer people on welfare and put more people to work, but that it has made little difference in lives of poor, socially or economically; former welfare recipients, employed in entry-level jobs, cannot afford to move from violent neighborhoods; there continue to be absent fathers, bare cupboards, epidemics of depression and temptations of drugs; street life tempts children whether parents work or not; new workers often resist workplace rules and boss's authority, prompting much job-hopping; working mothers have less time for their children; prospects of poor children may depend more profoundly on whether they have support of their fathers than whether their mothers move from subsistence welfare checks into subsistence jobs; photos (L)
docs.snippet: So, did it work?    Whatever else can be said about Wisconsin's crusade to end welfare -- whether one judges it kind or cruel, whether one thinks it left the safety net stronger or in shreds -- the effort achieved two things.

keywords.value: WORKFARE AND EMPLOYMENT OF WELFARE RECIPIENTS

docs.lead_paragraph: BY the year 1000, homeowners throughout the world enjoyed a remarkable range of creature comforts: coal stoves in China; crystal tableware in Baghdad; libraries in Ghana. All and all, it wasn't a bad time to be alive -- unless, of course, you lived in Europe. Peasants there dwelt in filthy one-room hovels heated by an open fire. The family, along with the goat, huddled on a single vermin-infested straw mat. Not that kings and queens in gloomy castles had it much better. Privacy was nonexistent, and the nobility, one historian has written, ''didn't so much live in their houses as camp in them.'' They spent most of their time on the road, visiting far-flung estates. Tellingly, the French and Italian words for furniture at this time -- mobilier and mobilia -- meant ''movables.'' It would be a while before Europeans settled down.

headline.main: Once Upon a Time, Only Kings Had Castles; Milestones, Millstones As Design Marches On

docs.abstract: Chronology of domestic achievements of last 1,000 years; drawings; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Magellan Health Services Inc. said today that the Justice Department is conducting a nationwide Medicare fraud investigation of Charter psychiatric hospitals, in which Magellan holds a 10 percent stake. Magellan, which is based in Columbia, Md., manages psychiatric health plans, and Charter Behavioral Health Systems L.L.C. also face a Justice Department investigation into whether the psychiatric hospitals failed to provide medically necessary treatment, Magellan said in its annual report filed Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

When a company provides health insurance to its employees, it is an employee benefit that is fully tax-deductible.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You say (''Two Visions on Health Care,'' editorial, Dec. 27) that there are two ways to achieve universal health care coverage: mandatory or voluntary. But in fact, voluntary universal coverage is an oxymoron.

headline.main: Bradley vs. Gore, on Health Care

docs.abstract: Roger W Birnbaum letter on Dec 27 editorial on Vice Pres Gore's and Bill Bradley's differing visions on health care
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    You say (''Two Visions on Health Care,'' editorial, Dec. 27) that there are two ways to achieve universal health care coverage: mandatory or  voluntary. But in fact, voluntary universal coverage is an oxymoron.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Two Visions on Health Care'' (editorial, Dec. 27): An alternative is clearly needed. At best, Al Gore's plan would cover no more than 12 million of the country's 44 million uninsured; it would likely include significantly fewer. Bill Bradley's proposal would likewise fail to guarantee universal coverage; moreover, it would privatize or eliminate Medicaid, and lavish 200 billion tax dollars on private insurers. In contrast, both the Congressional Budget Office and the General Accounting Office say a Canadian-style single-payer plan would save enough to cover all 44 million uninsured.

headline.main: Bradley vs. Gore, on Health Care

docs.abstract: Joanne Landy letter on Vice Pres Gore's and Bill Bradley's health-care proposals (Dec 27 editorial)

docs.lead_paragraph: The doctor you see through a workers' compensation network may not pamper you, but you will be back at work just as soon as if you had seen your own doctor, and you will be doing employers a favor by helping to cut costs. So says a recent study by the Workers Compensation Research Institute. It found that using network providers is far cheaper and refuted contentions that the networks save by reducing quality of care, which in turn delays return to work and increases indemnity payments for an employee who needs to be compensated for lost wages.

headline.main: Bending the Cost Averages for Those Aching Backs

docs.abstract: Study by Workers Compensation Research Institute shows that use of workers' compensation network provider is far cheaper than seeing personal physician and refutes contentions that networks save by reducing quality of care, which in turn delays return to work and increases indemnity payments for employee who needs to be compensated for lost wages; network prices result in 34 percent of cost reduction, but bulk of savings, 66 percent, is result of use of fewer services; for back pain, average number of office visits in nework was 4.2, compared with 5.3 out of network; graphs (M)
